title: Chris the sheep with the famously overgrown fleece dies aged 10

A sheep who found fame thanks to his heavily overgrown fleece has died aged 10.

Chris was spotted in 2015 living in the wild carrying an estimated six years worth of wool.

His entire body and most of his face had been completely overtaken by his incredible fleece coat - before he underwent a much needed makeover.

His carers, at a New South Wales farm in Australia, have now said the "friendly soul" died of old age.

The Little Oak Sanctuary wrote online: "We are heartbroken at the loss of this sweet, wise, friendly soul."

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

(Image: © AFP/RSPCA)

After being discovered in the wild near Canberra, experts feared for Chris' health due to the 40kg weight of the wool.

But national shearing champion, Ian Elkins, helped create a whole new look for Chris.

Elkins said he had never seen a sheep like it in his 35 years of shearing.

Speaking at the time, RSPCA boss Tammy Ven Dange said Chris' new look changed him from a "very shy sheep" to one "wanted cuddles all the time".

After Chris hit headlines for his unique look and then suave makeover, hundreds of Australians volunteered to adopt him.

(Image: X80001)

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

His mammoth wool coat was later put on display at the National Museum of Australia and his story was also recorded in a picture book for the RSPCA.

According to carer Kate Luke, who told The Canberra Times that his "death came out of the blue".

The sanctuary added that while Chris was best known for his fleece, to staff he had been "so much more".

Chris’s fleece beat Shaun from Tasmania (23.5kg) and New Zealander Shrek (27kg).
description: Chris was spotted in 2015 living in the wild carrying an estimated six years worth of wool and weighing an incredible 40kg
